text: Lewis Hamilton secured his seventh World Drivers’ Championship in 2020, tying Michael Schumacher’s record and strengthening Mercedes' dominance in the hybrid era.
The 2020 Formula 1 season was heavily affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a revised calendar that included several circuits returning after long absences.
Max Verstappen delivered a strong performance in 2020, becoming the only non-Mercedes driver to consistently challenge Lewis Hamilton throughout the season.
The 2020 Turkish Grand Prix became iconic due to slippery track conditions, allowing Lance Stroll to take his first career pole position.
Sergio Pérez claimed his first Formula 1 victory at the 2020 Sakhir Grand Prix after recovering from an early collision that dropped him to last place on lap one.
George Russell nearly won the 2020 Sakhir Grand Prix while substituting for Lewis Hamilton, showcasing his exceptional potential with Mercedes.
McLaren finished third in the 2020 Constructors’ Championship, marking their best performance in nearly a decade.
The 2020 Emilia Romagna Grand Prix returned to the calendar for the first time since 2006, held at the historic Imola circuit.
The Bahrain International Circuit hosted two races in 2020: the Bahrain Grand Prix and the shorter Sakhir Grand Prix layout.
Renault rebranded to Alpine for the 2021 season, adopting a new French racing identity with a blue livery.
Lewis Hamilton and Max Verstappen engaged in an intense title fight during the 2021 season, producing one of the closest championship battles in F1 history.
The 2021 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix ended with a controversial safety car decision that altered the championship’s outcome.
Max Verstappen won his first World Drivers’ Championship in 2021 following a season filled with wheel-to-wheel battles against Lewis Hamilton.
The Jeddah Corniche Circuit made its debut in 2021 as one of the fastest street circuits on the Formula 1 calendar.
The Dutch Grand Prix returned in 2021, offering a high-banked circuit at Zandvoort, and drawing massive support for Max Verstappen.
Daniel Ricciardo secured McLaren’s first win since 2012 by winning the 2021 Italian Grand Prix at Monza.
Lando Norris narrowly missed his first victory at the 2021 Russian Grand Prix after a late-race rain decision affected his tire strategy.
Ferrari showed major improvement in 2021, with Charles Leclerc and Carlos Sainz forming one of the strongest driver pairings on the grid.
Aston Martin struggled in 2021 despite high expectations, largely due to aerodynamic rule changes that impacted their low-rake car design.
Williams achieved a breakthrough season in 2021, scoring points in multiple races after years at the back of the field.
The 2022 season introduced radical new aerodynamic regulations designed to reduce dirty air and improve overtaking.
Ferrari started the 2022 season strongly with the F1-75, earning multiple wins early in the year.
Red Bull gained momentum throughout 2022, ultimately dominating the championship with their RB18 car.
Mercedes struggled with porpoising issues in 2022 due to the new ground-effect regulations introduced that year.
Max Verstappen set a new record with 15 race wins in the 2022 season, surpassing the previous single-season victory record.
Charles Leclerc won the 2022 Bahrain Grand Prix, securing Ferrari’s first win since 2019.
The Miami Grand Prix joined the Formula 1 calendar in 2022 with a circuit built around Hard Rock Stadium.
Valtteri Bottas had a strong debut season with Alfa Romeo in 2022, scoring consistent points early in the year.
Fernando Alonso returned to the spotlight in 2022 with Alpine, showing competitive pace and strong qualifying performances.
Kevin Magnussen returned to Haas in 2022, scoring a surprising fifth place at the season opener in Bahrain.
The 2023 season saw Red Bull achieve historic dominance, winning all but one race throughout the year.
Max Verstappen won 19 races in 2023, setting a new all-time record for most wins in a single Formula 1 season.
Aston Martin experienced a dramatic performance surge in early 2023, with Fernando Alonso earning multiple podiums.
McLaren introduced major upgrades mid-season in 2023, transforming the car into one of the fastest on the grid.
Oscar Piastri claimed his first Formula 1 podium in 2023 and later won the Qatar Sprint race.
Mercedes improved throughout the 2023 season but continued to struggle due to the limitations of their zero-sidepod design.
Ferrari ended Red Bull’s winning streak in 2023 when Carlos Sainz won the Singapore Grand Prix.
The Las Vegas Grand Prix returned to Formula 1 in 2023 with a brand-new street circuit on the Las Vegas Strip.
AlphaTauri underwent major structural changes in 2023 as the team prepared for a future rebranding.
Williams showed significant improvement in 2023 with strong performances from Alex Albon.
The 2024 season introduced additional calendar changes, including the return of the Chinese Grand Prix after several cancellations.
Ferrari’s SF-24 proved more competitive in 2024, bringing the team back into regular contention for podium finishes.
Mercedes introduced the W15 in 2024, a major redesign intended to move away from the troubled zero-sidepod era.
Lando Norris earned his first career victory at the 2024 Chinese Grand Prix after a flawless performance.
Red Bull remained competitive in 2024, though rival teams began closing the performance gap.
Yuki Tsunoda continued his strong development with the newly branded RB team in 2024.
The 2024 Japanese Grand Prix saw record attendance, largely due to the popularity of home driver Yuki Tsunoda.
Sauber continued preparation for their transition to the Audi works team scheduled for 2026.
Haas introduced a revised technical structure in 2024 following multiple seasons of limited competitiveness.
The 2024 season featured intense midfield battles between teams like Williams, RB, Haas, and Alpine.
Monza continued to be known as the Temple of Speed, hosting some of the fastest top-speed measurements in the 2020–2024 era.
Silverstone remained one of the most iconic races on the calendar, known for its fast-flowing corners such as Maggotts and Becketts.
The Circuit of the Americas in Austin remained a highly popular race, attracting large crowds each season from 2020 to 2024.
The Singapore Grand Prix maintained its reputation as one of the most challenging night races due to humidity and tight track boundaries.
The Mexican Grand Prix continued to celebrate Sergio Pérez as its local hero, drawing massive fan support throughout the early 2020s.
In the 2020 Formula 1 season, Lewis Hamilton secured his seventh World Drivers' Championship, tying Michael Schumacher's record.
The 2020 Austrian Grand Prix marked the beginning of a heavily modified season due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
McLaren's driver pairing of Lando Norris and Carlos Sainz delivered one of the most consistent midfield performances in the 2020 season.
The 2021 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix featured one of the most controversial endings in F1 history involving Max Verstappen and Lewis Hamilton.
Max Verstappen claimed his first World Championship title in 2021 with Red Bull Racing Honda.
The 2021 season introduced new budget cap regulations, aiming to reduce performance gaps between teams.
George Russell joined Mercedes as a full-time driver for the 2022 Formula 1 season, partnering with Lewis Hamilton.
Ferrari showed strong early performance in the 2022 season with Charles Leclerc winning in Bahrain and Australia.
The 2022 technical regulations introduced ground-effect aerodynamics to reduce dirty-air turbulence.
Red Bull Racing dominated the 2022 season, with Max Verstappen achieving a record-breaking 15 wins.
The 2023 Las Vegas Grand Prix returned Formula 1 to the Vegas Strip for the first time since the 1980s.
Oscar Piastri made his Formula 1 debut with McLaren in 2023 and quickly earned a sprint race win in Qatar.
The 2023 season saw Aston Martin rise significantly in performance with Fernando Alonso scoring multiple podiums.
Lewis Hamilton achieved a record-extending 104th pole position during the 2023 season.
During the 2023 season, Sergio Pérez faced inconsistent form despite driving the championship-winning Red Bull RB19.
The 2023 Singapore Grand Prix ended Red Bull's winning streak, with Carlos Sainz taking victory for Ferrari.
The 2024 season introduced new sustainable fuel developments as F1 prepared for major 2026 regulation changes.
In 2024, Mercedes introduced a revised chassis concept following difficulties with their 2022 and 2023 packages.
The 2024 Japanese Grand Prix at Suzuka highlighted McLaren's improved pace with Lando Norris finishing on the podium.
Charles Leclerc earned his first Monaco Grand Prix win in 2024, fulfilling a long-awaited home victory.
The 2024 Miami Grand Prix showcased strong competition between Red Bull and Ferrari for the championship lead.
Alpine struggled during the 2024 season due to poor chassis performance, leading to major internal restructuring.
Williams continued their rebuilding phase in 2024 with Alex Albon leading the team’s development efforts.
The Circuit of the Americas in Austin remained a fan-favorite venue between 2020 and 2024 due to its challenging corners.
Since 2020, the Bahrain International Circuit has frequently hosted season-openers due to logistical stability.
The Imola Grand Prix returned to the Formula 1 calendar in 2020 after a long hiatus.
Zandvoort rejoined the Formula 1 schedule in 2021, becoming the home race of Max Verstappen.
Fernando Alonso continued to demonstrate strong performance into his 40s, earning multiple podiums between 2020 and 2024.
Sebastian Vettel retired from Formula 1 at the end of the 2022 season after a 15-year career.
Valtteri Bottas transitioned from Mercedes to Alfa Romeo in 2022, taking on a leadership role within the team.
Yuki Tsunoda made his Formula 1 debut with AlphaTauri in 2021, becoming the first Japanese driver on the grid in years.
Mick Schumacher made his Formula 1 debut with Haas in 2021, continuing the Schumacher family legacy.
The 2021 Belgian Grand Prix was stopped after only a few laps due to extreme rain, marking one of the shortest races ever.
The 2022 Canadian Grand Prix featured a close battle between Max Verstappen and Carlos Sainz for the race victory.
George Russell earned his maiden Formula 1 win at the 2022 São Paulo Grand Prix.
Logan Sargeant joined Williams in 2023, becoming the first American F1 driver in several years.
Pirelli remained the exclusive tire supplier for Formula 1 from 2020 through 2024.
The Red Bull RB19 from 2023 is widely considered one of the most dominant cars in F1 history.
The 2024 Chinese Grand Prix returned to the calendar after being absent since 2019 due to the pandemic.
Between 2020 and 2024, Ferrari continued development of its driver lineup centered around Charles Leclerc and Carlos Sainz.
Lewis Hamilton announced his move to Ferrari for the 2025 season, a decision revealed during the 2024 championship.
